measured_by: Likert agreement with statements such as “I’m 100% certain that Harrison is guilty of theft” (-3 to +3 scale)
justification: “Participants indicated the extent to which they agreed or disagreed with the following statements: 'I'm 100% certain that Harrison is guilty of theft' … Responses were on a Likert scale from −3 ('Strongly disagree') to 3 ('Strongly agree').”

measured_by: 7-point adjective rating scale on goodness, badness, warmth, coldness
justification: “Global evaluations of the defendant: how good of a person he is; how bad of a person he is; how warm of a person he is; how cold of a person he is. Participants responded to each question on a 7-point scale.”
“Participants rated the probability that each theory was true, from 0% to 100%.” (Study 5) and “replacing the slider scale with a dropdown list of probabilities… 24 options.” (Study 6).

topic_or_construct: advocacy bias in belief about guilt
measured_by: binary response to target question ‘Is Harrison guilty of theft?’ within a nine-item yes/no quiz
justification: “Participants answered a series of nine yes-or-no questions including the target question: ‘Is Harrison guilty of theft?’ … Incorrect response to this critical trial indexed bias.”

measured_by: mouse-cursor trajectory deviation during yes/no click
justification: “We expected all participants to click 'yes,' but recorded mouse cursor trajectories as participants clicked a button labeled 'yes' or 'no'.”

measured_by: reported worst acceptable plea-deal sentence length (1-14 years)
justification: “Participants reported the worst offer they would accept … The response scale ranged from one to fourteen years. Answers constituted participants' reservation points.”

measured_by: percentage estimate of jury convicting the defendant
justification: “Participants guessed the probability of the jury finding the defendant guilty.”
